fields.description: In a deployment where registration network is not reachable from the VMs, the Imaging Worker will not function as it won't be able to contact the DNS server IP address returned in 'user-data' (which is the IP address seen in euca-describe-services for the 'dns' service). The symptom is that the tasks that rely on the Imaging Worker (import-volume, import-instance, and run-instance of a paravirtual image) will be pending for a long time until they timeout.
fields.summary: Imaging Worker does not work when "registration" net is isolated from "public" net

comments.body:
More data on this issue - there appear to be two parts:

TLDR: my understanding: since VMs are running on a network that is considered a 'user' network, they should always use the 'user' service endpoints.  In other words, what ends up in eucarc for users is what VMs need to use to access eucalyptus services (this is a system 'guarantee').  Using internal eucalyptus registration IPs from VMs *may* work, but cannot be depended on since we explicitly enable users to run network topologies where VM networks are isolated from eucalyptus registration networks.

This is relevant to topologies where the VMs cannot communicate with Eucalyptus components on their registration IPs (which is a topology feature that is offered for users who wish to run with a eucalyptus mgmt network that is separate from the VM network for performance, logical, and isolation reasons).  

NOTE: in the below example, 2.0.0.0/24 is my 'eucalyptus registration' network.  3.0.0.0/24 is my VM private network.  5.0.0.0/24 is my 'public network' for both VM public and Eucalyptus user facing service IPs.  The CLC/DNS is on N.0.0.1, where N is either '2' or '5' as above.

1) when the imaging worker is run, the user data contains:

{code}
[root@ip-3-0-0-44 eucalyptus-imaging-worker]# curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/user-data/
euca-c2V0dXAtY3JlZGVudGlhbA==
imaging_service_url=imaging.localhost;log_server_port=514;compute_service_url=compute.localhost;dns_server=2.0.0.1;euare_service_url=euare.localhost;
{code}

and I observe that there is a cronjob that runs '/usr/libexec/eucalyptus-imaging-worker/dns-update' which explicitly pulls that dns_server value out of user data and places it in /etc/resolv.conf.  Since the value supplied is the CLC 2.0.0.1 IP (which is not accessible from VMs), DNS resolution fails.

   - observation: when either remove the bit that modifies resolv.conf, or explicitly change it to 5.0.0.1 (which is the value that is being set there by default, from DHCP), then DNS resolution functions properly.

The second issue is regarding the imaging URLs that are being used by the imaging worker process.  Note that, in the output below (from worker.log), the URLs contain again 2.0.0.1, which is inaccessible, as the objectstorage gateway.  This appears to be the case whether or not I have DNS enabled on the CLC.  
   - observation: note that, since I run this cloud with DNS enabled and 'PROPERTY	dns.services.hostmapping	5.0.0.0/24->5.0.0.0/24', either the public IP of the objectstoragegateway or the hostname of the objectstoragegateway would work in the URL.  

{code}
root@ip-3-0-0-44 eucalyptus-imaging-worker]# nslookup 
> server 5.0.0.1
Default server: 5.0.0.1
Address: 5.0.0.1#53
> objectstorage.localhost
Server:		5.0.0.1
Address:	5.0.0.1#53

Name:	objectstorage.localhost
Address: 5.0.0.1
> 
{code}

{code}
2014-05-21 15:41:33,612 worker [DEBUG]:main loop running with instance_id=i-b0a9bfbe
2014-05-21 15:41:33,612 worker [INFO]:Querying for new imaging task
2014-05-21 15:41:48,062 worker [DEBUG]:(import-is-3bb14744) floppy disk mounted on /var/lib/eucalyptus-imaging-worker/floppy
2014-05-21 15:41:48,151 worker [DEBUG]:(import-is-3bb14744) floppy disk unmounted on /var/lib/eucalyptus-imaging-worker/floppy
2014-05-21 15:41:48,468 worker [INFO]:(import-is-3bb14744) Processing import task instance-store conversion task - id: import-is-3bb14744, bucket: euca-internal-sx0rb-emis-centos6-bucket, prefix: euca-centos6.4-ec2user-201
3.07.12-x86_64.img, manifests: 
import-image (id=eki-cc88fca9,format=KERNEL,manifest_url=http://imaging@2.0.0.1:8773/services/objectstorage/045344-download-manifests/DM-import-is-3bb14744-euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img-KERNEL?Expires=140070
4894&AWSAccessKeyId=AKI4LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC&Signature=bZYo9DKslzJXHXkXf3EburHsDqo%3D)
import-image (id=eri-3b8d34ca,format=RAMDISK,manifest_url=http://imaging@2.0.0.1:8773/services/objectstorage/045344-download-manifests/DM-import-is-3bb14744-euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img-RAMDISK?Expires=1400
704898&AWSAccessKeyId=AKI4LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC&Signature=FzHTn3fUzTyV0rWAwQKVzcuRBFg%3D)

1400704903&AWSAccessKeyId=AKI4LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC&Signature=q81r1dhmPXKmS4EmgzLKeibCVhM%3D)
2014-05-21 15:41:48,469 worker [DEBUG]:(import-is-3bb14744) Running /usr/libexec/eucalyptus/euca-run-workflow down-bundle-fs/up-bundle --image-manifest-url=http://imaging@2.0.0.1:8773/services/objectstorage/045344-download
-manifests/DM-import-is-3bb14744-euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img-PARTITION?Expires=1400704903&AWSAccessKeyId=AKI4LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC&Signature=q81r1dhmPXKmS4EmgzLKeibCVhM%3D --kernel-manifest-url=http://imaging@2
.0.0.1:8773/services/objectstorage/045344-download-manifests/DM-import-is-3bb14744-euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img-KERNEL?Expires=1400704894&AWSAccessKeyId=AKI4LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC&Signature=bZYo9DKslzJXHXkXf3Ebur
HsDqo%3D --ramdisk-manifest-url=http://imaging@2.0.0.1:8773/services/objectstorage/045344-download-manifests/DM-import-is-3bb14744-euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img-RAMDISK?Expires=1400704898&AWSAccessKeyId=AKI4
LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC&Signature=FzHTn3fUzTyV0rWAwQKVzcuRBFg%3D --emi=emi-dd56487c --eki=eki-cc88fca9 --eri=eri-3b8d34ca --decryption-key-path=/var/lib/eucalyptus-imaging-worker/node-pk.pem --encryption-cert-path=/var/lib/eucaly
ptus-imaging-worker/cloud-cert.pem --signing-key-path=/var/lib/eucalyptus-imaging-worker/node-pk.pem --prefix=euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img --bucket=euca-internal-sx0rb-emis-centos6-bucket --work-dir=/mnt/im
aging --arch=x86_64 --account=309901798188 --access-key=AKI4LP8GEJ8H1P51UCFC --object-store-url=http://2.0.0.1:8773/services/objectstorage --upload-policy={"expiration":"2014-05-23T03:26:31.825Z","conditions":[{"bucket": "
euca-internal-sx0rb-emis-centos6-bucket"},["starts-with", "$key", "euca-centos6.4-ec2user-2013.07.12-x86_64.img"],{"acl":"aws-exec-read"}]} --upload-policy-signature=AtasPVqty2l0k/C27SXdskauM2E= --cloud-cert-path=/var/lib/
eucalyptus-imaging-worker/cloud-cert.pem
{code}

Thanks for the detailed summary, [~nurmi]! I will expand on what he wrote a little bit more, identifying a likely third problem with the current implementation and outlining a range of short-, medium-, and long-term solutions:

- *Problem 1:* _Incorrect (internal) DNS server IP supplied via user-data_ (as explained in detail above). The solution is probably to return the correct, external, IP for the DNS server in {{dns_server=}} value of user-data. We suspect the same change should be made to the ELB service user-data. (It would be great if [~spark] could confirm that changing {{dns_server=}} won't lead to some subtle problem.)

- *Problem 2:* _Imaging service is internal and thus not accessible on the public network._ The medium-term solution is to (temporarily) make the imaging service one of the user-facing services. (This may have security implications, so it would be great if [~rusvika] considered them.) Long-term solution we briefly discussed is to switch from a custom work-polling mechanism used by the Imaging Service to a standard mechanism, namely Simple Workflow Service, once that is available.

- *Problem 3:* _Download manifests use registration-network IPs, which are not reachable from the Imaging Worker._ Since download manifests are also used by Node Controllers, which are on registration network, but not necessarily the public network, the solution needs to be more sophisticated than switching to using public-network IPs. Either download manifest generation logic will have to take into account the consumer of the manifest or -- better -- download manifests would use DNS names, which should resolve into correct IPs (either on registration net or on public net), depending on the source of the query. The latter solution, however, requires a functioning DNS server (without delegation turned on necessarily) in Eucalyptus, which I am not 100% sure is enabled in all configurations (this is something to verify).

The short-term solution is the workaround proposed by [~nurmi] above. We should document it with a Knowledge Base article for 4.0.0. [~vasya] will investigate shortly if the medium-term solutions proposed above are feasible for 4.0.1. If not, they will have to be 4.1 material.

[~dmitrii], (re. problem 2) the summary should state the issue is the imaging service is not accessible on the public network.

This may also be of interest in the long term:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_DHCP_Options.html

FYI - in MANAGED* modes, the workaround should be applied at the CC (can be statically set in /etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload).  For example:

-A PREROUTING -d 192.168.249.19/32 -j DNAT --to-destination 173.205.188.38

is the rule in place on the ECC, where VMs cannot reach the registration network (192.168.249.0/24) but they can necessarily reach the public facing IPs (173.205.188.0/24).  Since the ECC has OSG and CLC on the same host (249.19), there is only one rule required.

-D
I will get this setup and hand it over to [~vasya]

[~vasya] [~dmitrii]

I have setup the system with 3 networks:
10.111.5.155

1) Public network for VM public ips and cloud requests: 10.111.0.0/16 (em1)
2) Private network for inter-VM traffic: 172.16.0.0/16 (em1.556 on VLAN 556) 
3) Component registration network: 172.17.0.0/16 (em1.557 on VLAN 557)

[~vasya] That was the attempt to solve the problem #1 in Dmitrii's comment above. IIRC, that did not solve the problem, because ServiceConfiguration does not have an idea of public/registration networks.

I expect there will be requirements from users which ask for access to object storage also be handled on a network other than the public network (i.e. do all my image downloading on the backend management network).
[~lwade], OSG would still be accessible at both networks. I was wondering if there are any need to have OSG accessible only via private network.
[~vasya] ah ok I see. I can't see that being a requirement.

commit c62cd7f17f4198583e60523461c4ba34ad5423ed
Author: Vasiliy Kochergin <vasya@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Mon Sep 22 10:50:34 2014 -0700

    - Removed DNS updater script from Imaging Worker and ELB VMs.
      They need to rely on regular DNS names resolution like all other VMs.
    - Use IP from registration network in download manifest generated for NC.
      Use public DNS names in download manifest generated for Imaging Worker.
    
    Fixes for: EUCA-9435
----
This should fix problem #1 and #3 described above by Dmitrii.

Problem #2 regarding exposing Imaging Service to the public net should be solved only in deployments where CLC does not have access to the public network. It will to be solved in a separate commit/fix. I've opened a separate EUCA-10002 bug to address this special use case.

I've used deployment described at https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/QA/Separate+networks+installation+with+EDGE to test changes.

Verified with the network topo described in attached sketch. Also worth noting
the 'METADATA_IP' in eucalyptus.conf on the NCs was set to the CLC's public ip, and the following dns properties were used...
{code}
[root@c-15 ~]# euca-describe-properties | grep dns
PROPERTY	bootstrap.webservices.use_dns_delegation	true
PROPERTY	bootstrap.webservices.use_instance_dns	true
PROPERTY	dns.dns_listener_address_match	10.111.1.50
PROPERTY	dns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.instancedata.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.ns.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.recursive.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.services.hostmapping	10.111.0.0/16->10.111.0.0/16
PROPERTY	dns.split_horizon.enabled	true
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.enabled	false
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.region_name	{}
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_default_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_regions	false
PROPERTY	dns.tcp.timeout_seconds	30
PROPERTY	loadbalancing.loadbalancer_dns_subdomain	lb
PROPERTY	loadbalancing.loadbalancer_dns_ttl	60
PROPERTY	objectstorage.s3provider.s3usebackenddns	false
PROPERTY	system.dns.dnsdomain	c-15.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
PROPERTY	system.dns.nameserver	nshost.localhost
PROPERTY	system.dns.nameserveraddress	172.16.30.50
{code}
Thanks,
-M

Just to be clear, for the Imaging Worker to function, DNS must be enabled. The configuration that [~mclark] mentioned above has been tested. If any of those DNS-related text fields are not set or if booleans are set differently, the Imaging Worker may not function. Specifically, in 4.0.2, {{system.dns.dnsdomain}} must _not_ be set to {{localhost}} for the Imaging Worker to be able to reach OSG for downloading images.
